docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Selig Neubardt, a Westchester obstetrician and gynecologist and an author who was a prominent early advocate for birth control and safe abortion, died on Aug. 24 in White Plains. He was 78 and lived in New Rochelle. The cause was pneumonia, said a son, Dr. Seth Neubardt, a spinal surgeon at White Plains Hospital Center, where his father died.

headline.main: Dr. Selig Neubardt Dies at 78; Early Birth Control Proponent

docs.abstract: Dr Selig Neubardt, Westchester obstetrician and gynecologist and advocate for birth control and safe abortion, dies at age 78 (S)
docs.snippet: Dr. Selig Neubardt was an obstetrician and gynecologist and an author who was a prominent early advocate for birth control and safe abortion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two men were charged with trying to smuggle 50 Mexicans into Los Angeles Harbor on a rented yacht, the authorities said. The boat was intercepted by the Coast Guard on Monday night near the entrance to the harbor. Among the human cargo was a 3-year-old boy and a woman in the final month of her pregnancy. The daylong cruise began in Ensenada, Mexico, and each passenger had paid $3,000, immigration authorities said. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Illegal Immigrants Found On Yacht

docs.abstract: Two men are charged with trying to smuggle 50 Mexicans into Los Angeles Harbor on rented yacht (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of girls in school and women in parliaments has risen, and their overall access to contraception has improved in the past decade, according to a new report by the United Nations Population Fund. The report cites 23 countries, including Zambia, Bangladesh, Guatemala and Paraguay, as having made especially significant improvements in conditions for women, particularly regarding reproductive health and education.

headline.main: U.N. Cites Gains for Women Worldwide, but Health Issues Linger

docs.abstract: UN Population Fund reports number of girls in school and women in parliaments has risen around world in past decade, with particular gains in 23 countries; reports women's overall access to contraception has improved, but pregnancy-related deaths remain high and HIV epidemic is exploding among women and children; findings are released at nongovernmental organization meeting in London (M)
docs.snippet: The number of girls in school and women in parliaments has risen, and their overall access to contraception has improved in the past decade.
